title: CNA Explains: What could have caused the Kuala Lumpur sinkhole, and are there warning signs?
description: Sinkholes often happen very suddenly. But can they be avoided or at least minimised?

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• A woman was walking on a pavement in Malaysia's capital when the ground suddenly caved in. But how did this happen, and could it have been avoided? 
  • A sinkhole is a hole in the ground that forms when water dissolves surface rock, until the ground above becomes unstable and collapses.
  • The study of geological maps can identify areas susceptible to sinkhole formation, but it cannot pinpoint specific sinkholes. The exact cause of the Kuala Lumpur sinkhole remains undetermined.

title: CNA Explains: What’s next for Thailand after a month of political chaos?
description: A leading opposition party disbanded. A sitting prime minister dismissed and quickly replaced – by the latest name in a powerful family dynasty. CNA’s Saksith Saiyasombut makes sense of what it all means for Thailand.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• On Aug 7, Thailand’s Constitutional Court dissolved the opposition Move Forward Party, kicking off a period of political upheaval that saw prime minister Srettha Thavisin disqualified a week later and Paetongtarn Shinawatra appointed as the country’s new leader within 72 hours. Thaksin Shinawatra also got a royal pardon shortening his parole, on the same weekend his youngest daughter Paetongtarn took the helm. 
  • Questions remain over whether Mr Thaksin will play some role in the new government, and whether Thai politics will return to stability or undergo more chaos ahead.
  • While voters become increasingly disaffected, Mr Thaksin remains at the centre of heated debates and his actions could determine not just his own political legacy but the future of Thailand’s battered democracy.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Beijing has been regularly inviting Myanmar’s junta-appointed ministers to China on various official visits, but ex-president Thein Sein's trip in late June followed by junta No 2 Soe Win's over a week later have attracted interest. Sources told CNA that Soe Win would have been invited to China earlier, if not for alleged issues with military chief Min Aung Hlaing. 
  • During his trip, Thein Sein was reportedly asked by China Foreign Minister Wang Yi to persuade Min Aung Hlaing to hand over power. Soe Win meanwhile likely sought China's help with fending off ethnic armies.
  • Observers and sources alike said China appears willing to continue supporting the junta and ensuring it doesn't fail amid strong resistance from the ethnic rebels.

description: Vaccines have already entered the conversation – though not in Singapore just yet.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Bird flu has been spreading around the world in recent years, and while there is no evidence of human-to-human transmission, that doesn't mean it's not possible, says an expert.
  • Singapore has no plans to vaccinate people against bird flu, citing WHO recommendations and noting that continually changing influenza virus strains would affect the usefulness of vaccines.
  • Even though Singapore remains free of the bird flu, it shouldn’t take things for granted and should be prepared with plans in place that can be quickly ramped up, says the expert.

title: CNA Explains: France's election has ended in a hung parliament. What happens next?
description: How was the far-right surprisingly thwarted, and what does it say about the wider picture in Europe?

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• The left-wing New Popular Front alliance won the most seats in the National Assembly, but fell short of securing an outright majority. French President Emmanuel Macron’s centrist Ensemble alliance meanwhile came in second while the far-right National Rally party and its allies was third.
  • With three years left on his term and unable to call for another election for the next 12 months, Macron is now tasked with forming alliances to run the country with an unruly parliament.
  • Analysts said results indicated the French’s determination to keep the far-right out of government, but the resurgence of the movement in Europe cannot be dismissed.

• Three town council estates in Singapore will step up culling and other control measures over the next six months to manage the pigeon population.
  • Pigeons carry diseases such as salmonella bacteria and their droppings soil public amenities.
  • But culling alone will not be an effective long-term solution to reduce the pigeon population, say authorities and animal welfare groups.
  • While reducing human food sources is one way to manage numbers, the problem of illegal bird feeding persists.

description: Is it true that lawyers' fees will eclipse the final sum?

fast.headline_ovride_for_shorts: CNA Explains: Who pays damages in motor accident claims and other common questions
fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Earlier in June, a Singaporean man was awarded S$4.7 million after suffering permanent injuries from a chain collision in Malaysia. The report prompted many questions from readers, including whether he could actually get the full sum and what would happen if Malaysian defendants disappear or renege on payment.
  • CNA addresses these with the help of lawyers and also answers some common queries on motor accident claims.
  • In general, Singapore has in place multiple legal mechanisms to ensure a claimant gets the money awarded to him in a court judgment, even if the defendant is uninsured, bankrupt or cannot be traced.
  • Singapore also protects claimants from high lawyer fees by delaying cost payments until the case concludes, then requiring the defendant to pay part of the costs to cover the bulk of legal expenses.

title: CNA Explains: What passengers and crew can do during flight turbulence
description: Buckling up even when the “fasten seat belt” sign is off and avoiding the restroom when the plane is flying over oceans - what experts recommend to stay safe in the event of extreme turbulence, like what happened to SQ321.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Experts told CNA that passengers should buckle up at all times while seated, even when the “fasten seat belt” sign is not on.
  • Children under the age of three should be held by their parents and have their infant seat belts fastened.
  • Passengers are advised to avoid the toilet when turbulence is likely, such as when the plane is over oceans, one expert said.
  • Even during such tense moments, cabin crew still need to maintain a high quality of service, a former SIA flight attendant told CNA: “Some of us may be very scared, but still need to pretend everything is okay, and to reassure passengers and let them know it’s fine.”

title: CNA Explains: How often does turbulence occur, and how did it affect flight SQ321?
description: The SQ321 incident highlights the potential dangers of turbulence, especially as scientists warn its occurrence could worsen with climate change.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Turbulence occurs when an aircraft is caught up in a sudden shift in airflow caused by changes in wind speed and direction.
  • Clear-air turbulence is often behind injuries as it cannot be detected and happens without warning; flight crew may not have ample time to instruct passengers to fasten their seatbelts.
  • Most turbulence-related injuries happen because passengers and crew members are not wearing their seatbelts.
  • Scientists have warned that severe turbulence has jumped by 55 per cent in the past 40 years, and is expected to increase further due to the impact of climate change.

title: CNA Explains: The FLiRT family of COVID-19 variants and what we know about the KP.2 strain
description: What are the KP.1 and KP.2 strains? Are they more infectious and are current vaccines effective against newer variants of COVID-19?

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• The KP.1 and KP.2 strains belong to a new family of subvariants called “FLiRT”, which are descendants of the JN.1 variant, an offshoot of the Omicron variant.
  • Singapore's Health Ministry said there are currently no indications that KP.1 and KP.2 are more transmissible or cause more severe disease than other circulating variants.
  • The current vaccine may be less effective in preventing infections with KP.1 and KP.2, said infectious diseases expert Leong Hoe Nam, although scientists note that vaccination is still the best bet against COVID-19.

description: With online personalities entering areas of finance and even governance, CNA looks at the extent of their "powers" and how they could be held more accountable.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Influencers have been in the news for stoking negative sentiment online against businesses – even causing one of them to consider legal action – and thus raising questions on whether too much power has been placed in the hands of these online personalities.
  • Experts say influencers are free to express their opinions but there are exceptions. They also have to abide by online marketing and social media use guidelines.
  • For the most part, influencers continue to be self-regulated and it's up to them to avoid courting controversy – or worse, getting “cancelled”.

author: Justin Ong Guang-Xi

#attributes.alt: 'No special immunity': The limits of influencers' powers and what businesses can do about a negative review
#attributes.title: 'No special immunity': The limits of influencers' powers and what businesses can do about a negative review

title: CNA Explains: China's EVs and the quest for global dominance
description: CNA looks at the story behind Beijing's EV boom, the hurdles ahead and what it means for perceptions of "Made-in-China" products.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• For the first time, Chinese firm BYD recently overtook Tesla as the world’s largest electric vehicle seller amid an industry boom that has seen smartphone makers Xiaomi and Huawei jumping into the fray.
  • Generous government subsidies and affordable prices are some driving factors, but intensifying competition, pushback to global expansion and wider geopolitics now stand in the way.
  • But at least one expert says the growing popularity of Chinese EVs shows that the country is "increasingly recognised" for its high-tech products rather than the old impression of cheap and low-value goods.

author: Lakeisha Leo

#attributes.alt: CNA Explains: China's EVs and the quest for global dominance
#attributes.title: CNA Explains: China's EVs and the quest for global dominance

title: CNA Explains: South Korea’s opposition won a landslide election. Now what?
description: President Yoon Suk Yeol will slip into “lame duck” status for the remainder of his term, observers say.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• South Korea's liberal opposition Democratic Party (DP) notched a landslide majority in a general election on Wednesday (Apr 10), retaining control of parliament and dealing a crushing blow to President Yoon Suk Yeol and his conservative People Power Party (PPP).
  • The vote was largely seen as a midterm referendum on Mr Yoon, who has three years left in office. He has vowed to reform state affairs and improve the people's livelihoods. 
  • According to the National Election Commission, turnout for the election was about 67 per cent of the 44.2 million eligible voters, the highest in 32 years.

author: Calvin Yang

#attributes.alt: CNA Explains: South Korea’s opposition won a landslide election. Now what?

description: The amount of criminal proceeds laundered is just one factor, says a lawyer.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:

  • Netizens have said these sentences are too light, considering the billions of dollars involved in their money laundering case.

title: CNA Explains: Six months into the war between Israel and Hamas — is an end in sight?
description: The conflict has sparked a humanitarian crisis leaving scores of Gazans without food, water and electricity.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• Many Gazans are facing unsanitary conditions and food shortage, as the delivery of aid is slowed by the cumbersome process of inspections of trucks into the enclave. 
  • Last month, the International Court of Justice, the world's top court, ordered Israel to "ensure urgent humanitarian assistance" in Gaza without delay. However, Israel did not abide by the ruling.
  • Mr Netanyahu is facing growing pressure, as Israelis are increasingly dissatisfied with his management of the ongoing conflict. Protesters have stepped up their demands for the government to secure the release of hostages still held by Hamas.

title: CNA Explains: Why did gold and global markets hit all-time highs at the same time?
description: Gold and stocks typically thrive under different circumstances, so why did they sail to all-time highs simultaneously? CNA spoke to analysts at three banks and a bullion dealer to find out.

fast.tldr_for_shorts:
• After reaching an all-time high in December last year, the price of gold has continued to surge in 2024, hitting new highs and trading at more than US$2,100 (S$2,820) an ounce since early March.
  • At the same time, global markets are also at or near all-time highs.
  • Expectations of interest rate cuts from the United States Federal Reserve are a key driver of the simultaneous surges, analysts told CNA.

  • Experts think that opposition Workers' Party chief Pritam Singh is unlikely to be disqualified due to the maximum $7,000 fine amount in each of his charges.
